post_text:
As we get closer to the start of the school year, I know that many parents are becoming anxious about where to send their children. Over the past week or two, parents have inquired about the possibility of joining an Imbler classroom virtually if they were not comfortable sending their child once we are allowed to provide on-site education. Up to this point, we have declined that request due to student privacy issues. However, we have figured out a way for this to work. Instructionally, we can not guarantee that this is the best practice, but it does allow you to keep your child at home and have an Imbler teacher. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me at the elementary office.
~Angie Lakey-Campbell, Superintendent/Elementary Principal

post_text:
First Day of School Changed
The Imbler School Board voted last night to postpone the start of school to August 31 rather than the originally planned August 24. The last day of school will be June 4. A revised calendar will be available later today.

post_text:
July 28, 2020

Staff, Students, Parents, and Community Members,

We continue to work hard to prepare to educate Imbler School District Students during the 2020-21 school year. As many of you may be aware, Governor Brown has announced new COVID-19 health and safety metrics for school districts. Currently, Union County does not meet the requirements set forth. You can find the new requirements at https://www.oregon.gov/oha/PH/DISEASESCONDITIONS/DISEASESAZ/Emerging%20Respitory%20Infections/Ready-Schools-Safe-Learners-Community-COVID-19-Metrics.pdf.

At this time, it seems there are more questions than answers. We hope to have more answers within the next few days. Once again, we ask for your patience as we work through this most current challenge.

post_text: Congratulations class of 2020! Many thanks to all the graduates and families for all the effort and successes along the way. The Imbler School Staff are grateful and blessed to have worked with such outstanding young individuals and families. We are also thankful for these beautiful flowers the senior parents gave to the staff at graduation. These flowers represent the beauty to us that your children have embodied in each staff member. Celebrate with family on this momentous day for you and our country!

post_text:
July 1, 2020

Parent(s),
Imbler School District is in the beginning stages of planning for the 2020-21 school year. Our planning committee had its second meeting yesterday, and we are about halfway through the planning process. We hope to be able to provide you with a draft document sometime next week in hopes of receiving your feedback. The guidance we are receiving from ODE is changing as we write our plan, which is a bit of a challenge.

Sincerely,
Angie Lakey-Campbell
Superintendent/Elementary Principal

The bus is scheduled to arrive at 9:50 AM on Esther Avenue, beginning at Hull Lane, making its way to the high school campus. Patrons are encouraged to stay in their cars and honk and wave as the bus passes.

post_text:
June 24, 2020
9:00 am

Good morning,
From my earlier correspondence, I have received messages from parents expressing a couple of concerns, and I’m guessing that many others may have similar concerns. As I mentioned earlier, we are in the beginning stages of our planning process. However, based on current guidance by ODE, we are plannning the following:
• Students will not be required to wear masks.
• All students will receive face to face instruction every day.

post_text:
June 24, 2020

Parents and community members,
I wanted to update you on the progress of our planning for opening school in the fall. The task is a very large one, and I am thankful that we have staff members willing to volunteer their time to assist in completing it. We had our first committee meeting yesterday. Because the needs of the elementary and secondary students are different, we have decided to divide our group into two-one group for each building and plan to meet again next week. As we make progress on the plan, we will be posting it to receive your input and feedback. Until that time, if you have questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact me at the elementary school office.

Angie Lakey-Campbell, Superintendent/elementary principal

post_text:
June 12, 2020

Parents and Community Members,
I’m sure most of you are aware that the Oregon Department of Education has released guidelines for schools to reopen in the fall. Mr. Mills and I have spent much of the past two days reading them as well as sample plans developed by other districts throughout the state. Like many of you, we do not believe that distance learning is suitable for the students of the Imbler School District. We have begun the initial stages of planning and are committed to creating a plan that will allow for face to face instruction in the fall, which will no doubt look different than it has in the past. The state will mandate much of our plan, and it will undoubtedly change as the summer and school year progress. We ask for your continued patience and support as we work our way through the new school year. Along with the patrons of our district, we continue to be committed to excellence in education!

Angie Lakey-Campbell
Superintendent/Elementary Principal

post_text:
The following information is for our seniors. Please pass the word!
1. Senior’s google accounts will be suspended July 1st.

2. If seniors want to save data from their accounts for use later they can use http://takeout.google.com. This allows them to take files from Drive, email, photos, and other items from their school account and save it to portable storage.

Also of note: If seniors need to create personal Google accounts, some advice to pass on using a professional account name vs a silly name might be a good idea for use in job hunting or college correspondence.
text:
The following information is for our seniors. Please pass the word!
1. Senior’s google accounts will be suspended July 1st.

2. If seniors want to save data from their accounts for use later they can use http://takeout.google.com. This allows them to take files from Drive, email, photos, and other items from their school account and save it to portable storage.

Also of note: If seniors need to create personal Google accounts, some advice to pass on using a professional account name vs a silly name might be a good idea for use in job hunting or college correspondence.

Round and Round

Traditionally on the last day of school, our buses have made several trips around the parking lot with teachers waving goodbye to students. There were no buses today, but teachers were still wishing their students all the best for the upcoming summer break! Thanks to all of the parents who participated in the fond farewells!

post_text:
Dear Parent(s),

We want to thank you all for your patience and grace as we worked our way through Distance Learning for All. During Teacher Appreciation Week, our teachers wanted to honor you, our students' first teachers, for the work you accomplished while schools were closed. As we look to next year, we realize that school will look different next year. We are asking for your feedback to help improve our practice. Below, you will find a link to a survey, which will be open until June 12. We appreciate any thoughts you are willing to give.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeS7Tgm0eV0Vago20EVSI3dY1lm-jYzN2A0pOK9c2R7EwU52g/viewform

post_text:
Graduation Plans

It has come to our attention that some folks in the community have questions regarding our high school commencement. When we learned that schools would remain closed for the remainder of the school year, we met with seniors and their parents to discuss what the rest of the school year would bring. During that meeting, we suggested that we move the graduation ceremony to July 4 at 10:00 AM in hopes that the state would be open by that time. Students and parents said that would work. We realize that moving the date may be an inconvenience for many of you, and it is challenging to sit by while other communities are conducting their ceremonies. We hope that we can have a larger gathering to honor our seniors for their accomplishments truly!

We realize that moving the date may be an inconvenience for many of you, and it is challenging to sit by while other communities are conducting their ceremonies. We hope that we can have a larger gathering to honor our seniors for their accomplishments truly!

post_text:
Parents,
I’m guessing many of you are aware of Governor Brown’s most recent press conference closing schools for the remainder of the year. It is with a broken heart I write to tell you that I have teachers reeling because they will not be allowed to have your children in their classrooms again this year.

As I have visited virtual classrooms over the past week, I have seen teachers connecting with students. Entering into this distance learning, I had a bit of anxiety about our ability to reach our students. However, I have seen teachers show love and concern for their students, and I was able to feel the emotion even through a screen.

If Mr. Mills and I had asked our teachers to develop distance lessons for our students, we would have rightly received pushback. However, when it has been our only option, teachers have put in countless hours learning how to serve students in this new way. We will continue to do our best to give your child the best education possible.

Stay safe.

post_text:
April 7, 2020

Parents,
As we continue in our extended school closure, we are well on our way to implementing distance learning for all. Your child should be meeting with his/her teacher(s) regularly, and teachers are providing work for students. Teachers are taking attendance as they connect with students. Because this is new territory for all of us, we appreciate your patience as we navigate and find our way.
Sadly, we are beginning to realize that we may not have the liberty of returning to our classrooms this spring, and distance learning may well be how we finish the school year. We ask that you encourage your child to complete the work that has been assigned by their teacher. If the tasks assigned are too much, please communicate with your teacher as we calibrate expectations. Also, as questions and confusions arise, please do not hesitate to reach out for assistance. If you are having technical difficulties, the Intermountain ESD has an available tech helpline. Please call 888-223-9593.
Stay safe.

post_text:
OPB Collaboration: In line with many other states, representatives from ODE, OAESD and a few districts coordinated input to OPB around educational programming. The following schedule will begin on OPB starting today (Monday, March 30). OPB TV channels are available through cable, satellite and free over-the-air using a digital antenna. More at //opb.org/tv.
Educational Programming schedule by topic and age range:
6:00 a.m.: Natural Science (Grades K-3)
6:30 a.m.: History (Grades K-3)
7:00 a.m.: Math (Grades K-3)
8:00 a.m.: Science (Grades K-3)
8:30 a.m.: Financial Literacy (Grades K-3)
9:00 a.m.: Science (Grades 4-8)
10:00 a.m.: History (Grades 4-8)
11:00 a.m.: Local: Natural Science, Arts, and Culture
11:30 a.m.: Local History
Noon: Social Studies and Science (Grades 4-8)
1:00 p.m.: Science (Grades 4-8)
2:00 p.m.: Literature and Liberal Arts (Grades 4-12)
3:00 p.m.: World History (Grades 9-12)
4:00 p.m.: U.S. History (Grades 9-12)

post_text:
The following was sent to me by a patron who received it on Facebook. The author is unknown.

The next week or two starts a new chapter in public education. There is a huge learning curve that students and teachers will be navigating together!!

As we embark on this thing called “distance learning,” I am asking my Facebook friends to refrain from publicly scrutinizing their children’s teachers/schools/district for the way they are teaching or the lessons they are assigning.

Please offer grace to your child’s teacher and other school personnel. I promise that educating your children is still their #1 priority. ❤️

They are about to navigate unchartered waters with little, to no prep time. This is a crisis, not a time to be playing armchair quarterback. They love our kids and will be doing their absolute best!

post_text:
Parents,
You should have had a teacher reach out to you by now. We are in the process of identifying students in need of devices to access materials teachers may post online. If you have not had anyone contact you and your child is in need of a Chromebook, please contact the district office on or after March 30.
Teachers will also be providing packets of information for students. Our plan is to have materials to students beginning April 1. Stay safe!

post_text: Due to Governor Brown's Executive Order 20-12, we are forced to close our playgrounds and outdoor sports courts.
text: Due to Governor Brown's Executive Order 20-12, we are forced to close our playgrounds and outdoor sports courts.

post_text: We wanted to reach out to assure you that one of our top priorities as a school district is supporting your family and your senior student through this time. This is also a top priority for the state department of education. We are working on a plan to help ensure that students will meet requirements and hopefully can graduate on time. Currently, that plan will include delivery of their education online, with virtual meetings and possibly some packet-based learning if needed. With that said, this situation has been changing daily and this is what we know at this time.

post_text:
The Oregon Department of Education on Tuesday 3/17 announced that Governor Kate Brown has extended the Statewide School Closure for students in Oregon through Tuesday, April 28. Through Executive Order 20-08, Governor Kate Brown ordered public schools to remain closed to students from March 16, 2020, through April 28, 2020, unless that period is extended or terminated earlier by the Governor.

ODE Press Release: https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/ORED/bulletins/281c059

Our school district is sharing this information with our students, families, and staff. We will be developing plans for this extended closure and will be providing information on a continuous basis.

Thank you.
shared_text:
Governor Kate Brown Extends School Closure
Through Executive Order 20-08, Governor Kate Brown ordered public schools to remain closed to students from March 16, 2020, through April 28, 2020, unless that period is extended or terminated earlier by the Governor.

Governor Kate Brown Extends School Closure

content.govdelivery.com
text:
The Oregon Department of Education on Tuesday 3/17 announced that Governor Kate Brown has extended the Statewide School Closure for students in Oregon through Tuesday, April 28. Through Executive Order 20-08, Governor Kate Brown ordered public schools to remain closed to students from March 16, 2020, through April 28, 2020, unless that period is extended or terminated earlier by the Governor.

ODE Press Release: https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/ORED/bulletins/281c059

Our school district is sharing this information with our students, families, and staff. We will be developing plans for this extended closure and will be providing information on a continuous basis.

Thank you.

Please use the link below to help us better understand individual student and family needs.

post_text:
Coronavirus Update –
In earlier correspondence, Imbler School District notified parents of the opportunity to obtain lunches for their children. To better protect staff and community health, the district will provide supplies for lunches on Monday, March 16, for those interested. Please contact the head cook, Tanya Corta, via email at tanya.corta@imblersd.org or by text at 208-402-3575. The supplies will be available at Imbler Elementary School at 11:00 am on Monday, March 16. Appropriate charges will apply.

post_text:
**Guidance & Best Practices for Schools**
The Oregon Health Authority (OHA) and the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) understand that many people have questions about what recent COVID-19 cases mean for the health of their children.
OHA and ODE and the Higher Education Coordinating Commission have issued guidance and best practices for schools, colleges and universities to guide decision-making concerning the novel coronavirus in Oregon.
At this time, the guidance recommends against closing schools and campuses where no cases of COVID-19 are present. It also recommends that schools, colleges, and universities consider all alternatives before closing a school, college or university in the event that a COVID-19 case is detected among students or staff.
To read the full guidance for schools: https://www.oregon.gov/oha/ERD/Pages/State-agencies-issue-COVID-19-guidance-Oregon-schools-universities.aspx

post_text:
***How are decisions made about closing schools or how long they should be closed?***
Typically, these decisions are made by school administrators, in consultation with state and local public health departments.

***How are decisions made about canceling extracurricular activities before or after school? How about cancellation of sporting or other events outside of my school district? ***
These decisions are made by affected schools in consultation with public health agencies. At this time, public health agencies in Eastern Oregon are not advising school closures.
Here is a link with more information from OHA and ODE: https://www.oregon.gov/ode/students-and-family/healthsafety/Documents/Questions-About-School-Closures.pdf

post_text:
How will I be told if someone at my child’s school is exposed or has COVID-19?
If this happens, your local health department and school district will work together to let you know. They will do this within rules set by the school district and local health department. If you have concerns, check with your child’s school to learn about their communicable disease prevention plan

post_text:
Nominations for the 2020 Crystal Apple "Excellence in Education" Awards are now open. These annual awards recognize outstanding educators and school staff in eastern Oregon school districts.

Those eligible to be nominated are full-time or part-time employees who have worked in the district for one year. Crystal Apple Awards can be given to principals, assistant principals, teachers, paraeducators, office staff, maintenance staff and other district staff. They can be nominated by administrators, teachers, paraeducators, school staff, students, parents or community members.

Deadline for nominations is April 1, 2020.
Nomination Form: https://imesd.k12.or.us/crystal-apple-award-nomination-form
Information Page: https://imesd.k12.or.us/crystalapple/home

post_text:
Do you like lending a helping hand? Tylie McKaig is having a dessert auction at Friday's basketball games on January 31, 2020, to help fund her senior project. The proceeds from the sale will go toward the purchase of items for gift bags for new mothers at Grand Ronde Birthing Center. If you would prefer to forego the dessert auction and help with purchasing, here's a list:

For Mom~fun water bottle, feel-good scented candle, hand sanitizer (safe for baby), Chapstick, small hand lotions, lip gloss, face mask, bath bombs, and care items.

For baby~ bottle scrubbers, toys, teddy bears, rattle, stocking caps, booties, receiving blankets, and burp rags.

post_text: La Grande School District Driver's Ed program is gearing up for another fun season of helping students learn valuable life skills. They will be running a spring, summer, and fall session this year. Space is limited by ODOT rules, so families need to sign-up as soon as they know they want to participate, and their student has a permit. Last year all sessions were filled, and we hope to repeat the same success. Check the Imbler School District website for further information.

post_text:
On Thursday, January 23rd, the Oregon Department of Education (ODE) released graduation rates for school districts in Oregon. These are 2018-19 graduation rates.

Imbler School District’s 4-year Cohort graduation rate is 100%. Angie Lakey-Campbell, district superintendent, said the district is very excited about its continued excellence in the graduation rate.

"Instilling an attitude of excellence and the commitment to achieve" has been the mission statement for the Imbler School District for many years. Teachers, parents, and community members have committed to the students of Imbler and established a culture where the common belief is that all students will graduate every year, Lakey-Campbell said.

To read the entire article, please visit: https://imbler.k12.or.us/article/district-celebrates-positive-graduation-rate

post_text:
Do you know a great teacher? The Oregon Department of Education, in partnership with the Oregon Lottery, is pleased to announce the continuation of Oregon Regional Teacher of the Year to honor exemplary educators in every region of the state!

Anyone can nominate a teacher! All Oregonians are encouraged to nominate their favorite teacher today at: https://oregonteacheroftheyear.org/nominate/

• Nominations are open statewide through January 31, 2020.
• Oregon Education Service Districts will select a winner from their region.
• Regional Teachers of the Year will be honored across the state in May 2020!
Regional Teachers of the Year will receive a cash prize of $500 and will be celebrated across the state.
text:

Anyone can nominate a teacher! All Oregonians are encouraged to nominate their favorite teacher today at: https://oregonteacheroftheyear.org/nominate/

• Nominations are open statewide through January 31, 2020.
• Oregon Education Service Districts will select a winner from their region.
• Regional Teachers of the Year will be honored across the state in May 2020!
Regional Teachers of the Year will receive a cash prize of $500 and will be celebrated across the state.

post_text:
The Imbler School District Board of Directors is seeking community input to complete a thorough evaluation of Superintendent Angie Lakey-Campbell. Responses will be accepted through January 13th, 2020.

Take the Community Superintendent Evaluation 2019 here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/7ZZDC5Y

Thank you.
text:
The Imbler School District Board of Directors is seeking community input to complete a thorough evaluation of Superintendent Angie Lakey-Campbell. Responses will be accepted through January 13th, 2020.

Take the Community Superintendent Evaluation 2019 here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/7ZZDC5Y

Thank you.

post_text:
FFA Excellence

Two of the premier FFA chapters in the northwest were able to learn from each other yesterday, November 19, 2019, when the Cambridge, Idaho chapter visited the Imbler, Oregon Chapter in Imbler. Officers from each chapter shared their reasons for being in FFA. Students were then grouped and shared the chapter program of activities.



Also, chapter advisors, Jodie Mink and JD Cant, two of the best in the business, had an opportunity to talk shop while the students interacted.
